stories.title: The Next Chapter
stories.intended_reader: Travelers interested in Regent's fleet future
stories.core_insight: Seven Seas Prestige will launch as Regent's largest and most innovative ship
stories.markdown:
**Seven Seas Prestige represents Regent's future—a new class ship that will establish new standards for ultra-luxury cruising.**

Prestige will carry approximately 850 guests, larger than Explorer Class's 750 while maintaining Regent's industry-leading space ratios. The design continues Regent's philosophy: every luxury included, every accommodation a suite.

The Prestige Class introduces features impossible on earlier ships. Expanded dining options. Enhanced wellness facilities. Larger suite categories. The evolution builds on Explorer Class success.

For Regent loyalists, Prestige promises the brand's values at new scale. For newcomers, she'll offer the most comprehensive expression of Regent's ultra-luxury vision.

For future planning: Seven Seas Prestige will define Regent's next era. Watch deployment announcements—inaugural season sailings attract travelers eager to experience new ships first.

stories.title: Evolution of Excellence
stories.intended_reader: Travelers interested in cruise ship design evolution
stories.core_insight: Seven Seas Prestige will continue Regent's 'perfecting perfection' approach
stories.markdown:
**Seven Seas Prestige will apply lessons from Explorer Class to create the most refined Regent ship yet.**

Regent's 'perfecting perfection' philosophy means each new ship iterates on predecessors. [Seven Seas Explorer](/ships/regent/seven-seas-explorer.html) established the template. [Seven Seas Splendor](/ships/regent/seven-seas-splendor.html) and [Seven Seas Grandeur](/ships/regent/seven-seas-grandeur.html) refined it. Prestige will advance the evolution further.

Design improvements will address what Explorer Class experience revealed. Traffic patterns, venue proportions, suite layouts—every element will reflect accumulated learning.

The larger capacity enables features impossible at smaller scale. Expanded specialty dining. Enhanced entertainment spaces. More suite categories. Size becomes opportunity.

For design appreciation: Seven Seas Prestige will represent Regent's most ambitious design statement. The ship will define what ultra-luxury means for the next decade.

stories.title: What to Expect
stories.intended_reader: Travelers considering booking future Prestige cruises
stories.core_insight: Seven Seas Prestige will offer Regent's most comprehensive all-inclusive experience
stories.markdown:
**Seven Seas Prestige will deliver Regent's comprehensive all-inclusive model with enhanced amenities and expanded offerings.**

The fundamentals will persist: every luxury included. Unlimited shore excursions. Premium beverages. Specialty dining. WiFi. Gratuities. The inclusions that define Regent will continue.

New offerings will expand beyond current ships. Additional dining venues. Enhanced wellness programming. Larger suites in new configurations. The evolution adds rather than replaces.

Booking strategy for new ships: inaugural sailings attract premium pricing and high demand. Later sailings offer operational maturity. Choose based on whether you prioritize being first or prefer proven operations.

For booking consideration: Seven Seas Prestige will offer newest expression of Regent luxury. Watch for opening announcements—popular itineraries book quickly.

stories.title: Why I'm Booking Prestige Solo for Her Inaugural
stories.core_insight: Seven Seas Prestige's inaugural season presents unique opportunities for solo travelers to be part of cruise history
stories.markdown:
**I've sailed Regent solo for eight years, ever since my divorce liberated me from a marriage where I'd forgotten my own preferences. When Seven Seas Prestige was announced, I knew immediately: I would be aboard her inaugural voyage, alone and perfectly happy.**

The decision wasn't impulsive. I've spent years learning what solo travel requires and what Regent delivers. The Explorer Class ships taught me that ultra-luxury and solo traveling aren't contradictory—they're complementary. A ship that treats every guest as worthy of attention naturally treats solo travelers as complete rather than incomplete.

My anticipation for Prestige centers on what the new ship promises. Larger capacity—850 guests—means slightly less intimate than Navigator but still manageable for solo travelers who want to be known without being overwhelming. The enhanced Compass Rose and expanded specialty dining venues mean more opportunities for those evening meals where solo status becomes social advantage rather than awkwardness.

I've learned that inaugural voyages attract particular passengers—experienced cruisers willing to pay premium prices, travel enthusiasts excited about new ships, Regent loyalists who want to witness the next chapter. These aren't the honeymooners and anniversary celebrants who dominate other voyages. They're people with interesting stories, comfortable with solo travelers, eager for shipboard conversation.

The all-inclusive model matters especially on inaugural sailings. The crew will be learning the ship—inevitable growing pains in new venues, unfamiliar traffic patterns, systems still being optimized. When everything is included, these imperfections become stories rather than frustrations. You're not calculating whether the learning curve diminished your value. You're participating in history.

I called my Regent travel advisor the day Prestige bookings opened. She's known me for years—understands my preferences for quieter deck locations, my love of afternoon tea, my need for crew who remember names quickly. She secured my Penthouse Suite on the inaugural Mediterranean voyage before I'd even reviewed the itinerary.

'You don't need to know where you're going,' she said. 'You need to know you're there from the beginning.'

She was right. I've sailed Mediterranean ports dozens of times. What I've never done is watch a Regent ship find her identity, experience crew developing rhythms, witness the moment when a vessel transforms from new construction to living community.

My solo status will serve me well on Prestige's inaugural. Without a travel companion's preferences to negotiate, I can explore freely—try every venue, join every activity, talk to every willing fellow passenger. I'll document the ship's first days for fellow solo travelers considering future voyages.

Seven Seas Prestige represents Regent's future. I want to be part of that future from day one. When Prestige matures into the fleet's flagship, I'll remember when she was new, when we were all learning her together, when solo travelers like me helped shape her culture.

The wait feels eternal. But I've been waiting eight years to find a ship worth being first aboard. Prestige is that ship.

I'll report back after the inaugural. Solo travelers, save your deposits. This is the one.

stories.title: Why We're Booking Three Generations on Prestige
stories.intended_reader: Families planning milestone voyages on new ships
stories.core_insight: Seven Seas Prestige's expanded capacity and enhanced amenities promise unprecedented multi-generational luxury
stories.markdown:
**My mother's 80th birthday falls during Seven Seas Prestige's inaugural season. We've been planning for three years—four generations, fourteen family members, the newest Regent ship. Nothing less would honor the woman who taught us to travel beautifully.**

Mom has sailed every Regent ship since Mariner's launch in 2001. She introduced me to cruising when I was reluctant, taught my children that travel was education, and insisted that grandchildren deserved the same quality she'd experienced. Her standard has always been Regent. For her milestone birthday, only their newest ship would do.

The logistical planning required extensive coordination. Four generations means radically different needs—my 80-year-old mother, my husband and me in our fifties, our adult children and their spouses in their twenties, and three grandchildren under ten. Explorer Class ships accommodated us adequately. Prestige's expanded capacity—850 guests with enhanced family amenities—promises to serve us better.

I've studied every available detail about Prestige's design. The expanded suite categories mean we can book interconnecting accommodations that keep grandchildren near parents while giving grandparents necessary quiet. The enhanced Compass Rose promises tables large enough for our entire family without the cramped configurations smaller ships require. The expanded specialty dining venues—rumored to include new concepts beyond the established Prime 7 and Chartreuse—mean we can celebrate Mom's birthday across multiple culinary experiences.

The all-inclusive model becomes essential with fourteen family members spanning four generations. I've organized multi-generational trips where cost allocation caused resentment—who pays for the children's excursions, whether grandparents should subsidize adult children's wine consumption, the endless calculations that poison family harmony. Regent eliminates these negotiations. Everything is included for everyone. Mom's birthday gift to the family is freedom from financial tension.

The shore excursions promise particular value. Prestige's inaugural Mediterranean itinerary includes ports we've visited before, but unlimited excursions mean we can experience them differently. My adventurous twenty-somethings can kayak while grandparents take gentle walking tours. Children can explore age-appropriate activities while parents enjoy wine tastings. Nobody compromises. Everyone experiences destinations according to their abilities and interests.

My mother doesn't know about the planning. She knows we're 'considering' a cruise for her birthday. She doesn't know that fourteen family members have been coordinating for three years, that deposits were placed before Prestige's keel was laid, that her travel advisor has been receiving monthly updates on construction progress.

The reveal will come at her 79th birthday dinner. We'll present a mock-up of our Prestige suite arrangement, an itinerary of the ports she's dreamed about, and the knowledge that her entire family prioritized being together on the ship that represents Regent's future.

I expect tears. I'm already crying as I write this.

Seven Seas Prestige will be new, untested, finding her rhythms. But our family will find our rhythms too—four generations learning a ship together, making memories that outlast any inaugural-voyage imperfections.

Mom taught us that travel creates family. Prestige will create the memory we'll share forever.

stories.title: Our Honeymoon on the Ship of the Future
stories.intended_reader: Couples planning honeymoons on new ships
stories.core_insight: Seven Seas Prestige offers engaged couples the opportunity to begin marriage on a ship beginning her own journey
stories.markdown:
**We're getting married in eighteen months, and we've already booked our honeymoon on Seven Seas Prestige. My fiance thinks I'm crazy. I think we're starting our marriage the way we intend to continue—with ambition and beauty.**

Michael and I met on a cruise—not Regent, unfortunately, but the experience taught us both that we were travelers who valued quality over quantity. Our early dates were planning future trips. Our engagement happened overlooking the Mediterranean from a hotel balcony. Our life together will be built on shared adventures.

When Regent announced Prestige, I saw our honeymoon. Michael worried about booking a ship that didn't exist yet—what if construction delays affected our wedding timeline? What if inaugural-voyage kinks diminished the experience? What if we'd invested thousands in a ship that disappointed?

I addressed each concern systematically. Regent's construction timeline allowed buffer room around our wedding date. Inaugural voyages attract premium passengers and heightened crew attention—the 'kinks' would be offset by exceptional service focus. And Regent's track record suggested Prestige would meet or exceed expectations.

Michael remained skeptical until I showed him the preliminary renderings. The enhanced Regent Suite designs. The expanded wellness facilities. The new dining concepts. The promise that Prestige would represent Regent's most ambitious expression yet.

'Our marriage should be ambitious,' I argued. 'Why shouldn't our honeymoon match?'

He agreed. We booked.

The anticipation has become part of our wedding planning. While other couples stress about centerpieces, we research Prestige's announced amenities. While friends debate reception venues, we analyze itinerary options. Our honeymoon isn't an afterthought—it's the adventure that wedding logistics merely precede.

The all-inclusive model particularly appeals to us. We're paying for our own wedding—no parental support, no family money—and the honeymoon budget is fixed. Knowing that Prestige includes everything means our honeymoon won't require the budgeting vigilance that wedding planning has demanded. For two weeks, we'll simply exist in luxury without calculating costs.

The unlimited shore excursions promise honeymoon adventures we couldn't otherwise afford. Every port becomes opportunity rather than expense. We've already researched Prestige's inaugural destinations—Mediterranean ports we've dreamed about, experiences we've postponed for 'someday.' Someday becomes honeymoon.

My vision for our first married days: waking in a Prestige suite, breakfast on our balcony watching new destinations emerge, exploring ports together, returning to a ship we're discovering alongside 850 fellow passengers on her inaugural season. Our marriage begins as Prestige begins—both relationships finding their rhythms, both futures unwritten.

Michael has caught my enthusiasm. He now checks Regent's website for Prestige updates more frequently than I do. He's researching inaugural-voyage passenger communities, wondering who else will share our honeymoon ship. He's invested.

We're starting our marriage on a ship that's starting her service. The parallel delights me. Prestige and Michael and I will grow together, all of us becoming whatever we're meant to become.

The wedding will be beautiful. The honeymoon will be the beginning of everything else.

stories.title: Why an 82-Year-Old is Booking the Newest Ship
stories.core_insight: Seven Seas Prestige offers experienced cruisers the chance to witness the future of ultra-luxury travel
stories.markdown:
**My children think I'm foolish—booking an inaugural voyage at eighty-two on a ship that doesn't exist yet. They worry about my health, my age, my ability to handle a new ship's learning curve. They don't understand that Prestige might be my last chance to see the future.**

I've sailed with Regent since before they were Regent—back when Radisson Seven Seas still owned the fleet. I witnessed Navigator's intimate revolution, Mariner's all-suite innovation, Voyager's all-balcony transformation. I sailed Explorer's inaugural season and watched her sisters Splendor and Grandeur continue the evolution. I've seen this cruise line grow from ambitious newcomer to ultra-luxury leader.

Prestige represents the next chapter. At eighty-two, I may not be here for the chapter after. If I want to witness Regent's future, Prestige's inaugural season is my opportunity.

The health concerns are valid but manageable. My cardiologist has cleared me for travel. My mobility limitations—cane required, stamina reduced—have been accommodated beautifully on previous Regent voyages. The accessibility coordination that impressed me on Grandeur will presumably translate to Prestige with enhancements appropriate to newer design.

The 'learning curve' my children fear actually appeals to me. Yes, new ships have imperfections—crew still learning traffic patterns, systems not yet optimized, inevitable adjustment periods. But inaugural voyages also bring heightened attention. When everything is new, everyone tries harder. I've experienced inaugural seasons before. The effort surpasses the imperfections.

My travel advisor understands my priorities. She's booking me a Penthouse Suite on Prestige's inaugural Mediterranean voyage—the same category I've sailed since Explorer, positioned for the views and accessibility I require. She's coordinated with Regent's special services team to ensure my needs are documented before crew assignments are finalized. By embarkation, my butler will know my morning routine, my dining preferences, my afternoon tea requirements.

The all-inclusive model matters especially at my age. I don't want to spend potentially limited years calculating value. I want to experience beauty without spreadsheets. Regent has always delivered that freedom. Prestige promises to expand it.

My children's deepest worry remains unspoken: what if something happens to me aboard a ship far from home? I've addressed this directly with my travel advisor. Medical evacuation coverage is in place. My advance directives are current. My family has full itinerary access. If my time comes aboard Prestige, I will be among people who've spent years caring for travelers like me.

There are worse ways to go than watching the Mediterranean from a Regent balcony.

But I expect to return from Prestige's inaugural with stories, not endings. I expect to tell my grandchildren about the newest expression of ultra-luxury cruising. I expect to watch crew find their rhythms and passengers become community. I expect to witness the future of the cruise line I've loved for decades.

At eighty-two, witnessing the future feels like privilege, not foolishness.

Seven Seas Prestige represents what Regent will become. I want to be there when she becomes it.

stories.title: Booking Prestige for the Woman I Was and the Woman I'm Becoming
stories.intended_reader: Widows considering significant voyages as markers of renewal
stories.core_insight: Seven Seas Prestige's inaugural season offers widows the symbolism of beginning anew alongside a ship doing the same
stories.markdown:
**My husband Robert died three years ago. We had booked Seven Seas Grandeur's inaugural for our 40th anniversary—a celebration that never happened. I've just booked Prestige's inaugural for myself. Not a memorial. A beginning.**

Robert and I were Regent loyalists for decades. We sailed every ship in the fleet at least once. When Grandeur was announced, the inaugural voyage seemed perfect for our milestone anniversary—the newest ship for forty years of marriage.

He died six weeks before departure. I cancelled everything and assumed I'd never cruise again.

Grief counseling taught me that assumptions need examination. A support group for widows introduced me to women who'd returned to travel, who'd reclaimed experiences death had threatened to steal. One woman described her first solo cruise—terrifying, then liberating, then essential to her recovery.

I rebooked Grandeur the following year. Solo. Prepared for grief to overwhelm me. Instead, the ship I'd planned to share with Robert became the ship where I learned I could travel without him. The crew accommodated my tears without excessive attention. Fellow passengers offered connection without intrusion. By voyage end, I'd laughed genuinely for the first time in months.

I've cruised Regent three times since—Grandeur twice, Splendor once—each voyage strengthening the identity I'm building as a solo traveler. Robert is always present. But he's present as companion to my adventures, not obstacle to them.

Prestige represents the next step. Not because I need a newer ship, but because I need the symbolism of beginning. Prestige will be finding her identity as I continue finding mine. We'll both be new versions of ourselves, testing capabilities, establishing rhythms, becoming whatever we're meant to become.

The inaugural voyage appeals specifically because it lacks Robert's memory. He never saw Prestige renderings, never discussed her specifications, never planned which suite category we'd book. This ship belongs to the woman I'm becoming, not the woman I was when we traveled together.

My travel advisor understood immediately when I explained my reasoning. She's booked me a Concierge Suite—smaller than the Penthouse Robert and I preferred, but appropriate for solo travel and my evolving preferences. She's connected me with fellow solo travelers considering Prestige's inaugural, potential companions for dining and excursions without the obligation of constant togetherness.

The all-inclusive model remains essential. I don't want to calculate whether experiences are 'worth it' when my emotional capacity is devoted to navigating new territory. Unlimited excursions mean I can say yes to adventures Robert would have enjoyed, experiencing ports for both of us without financial anxiety.

Prestige will carry Robert's memory. I'll toast him at the Compass Rose, order the wines he loved at Prime 7, watch sunsets from my balcony and imagine his commentary. But Prestige will also carry the woman I'm becoming—someone capable of booking inaugural voyages alone, someone who sees new beginnings as opportunity rather than terror.

Seven Seas Prestige launches into service the same season I launch into my fourth year of widowhood. We're both becoming something new.

Robert would be proud of the woman boarding that ship. I'm learning to be proud of her too.

stories.title: Why Prestige Represents Hope for Accessible Ultra-Luxury
stories.intended_reader: Travelers with disabilities evaluating new ship accessibility
stories.core_insight: Seven Seas Prestige's new construction offers unprecedented opportunity for accessibility integration from the design phase
stories.markdown:
**I've used a power wheelchair since a spinal cord injury at twenty-six. I'm forty-four now, and I've watched accessibility in cruising evolve from afterthought to consideration to, occasionally, genuine inclusion. Seven Seas Prestige represents what I've been waiting for: a ship designed from inception with travelers like me in mind.**

The distinction matters enormously. Older ships retrofitted for accessibility inevitably compromise—routes that feel like service corridors, 'accessible' suites that sacrifice luxury for functionality, accommodations that work but never delight. New construction eliminates these compromises. When accessibility is designed rather than added, the results are transformative.

I've sailed Regent's Explorer Class ships with positive experiences. The accessibility coordination was thorough. The crew was attentive. The accommodations functioned well. But I always felt the adaptations—the routes that differed from able-bodied passengers, the restaurants where my positioning options were limited, the shore excursions where accessibility was solved rather than celebrated.

Prestige promises something different. I've studied every available detail about her design specifications. The preliminary accessibility documentation suggests suites where wheelchair users experience the same views, same luxury, same beauty as any other guest. The public space plans show routing that integrates rather than segregates. The shore excursion protocols anticipate accessibility as standard rather than special request.

The enhanced medical facilities particularly interest me. Regent has always handled disability well—their medical teams understand complex needs, their coordination with specialized equipment providers is thorough. Prestige's expanded medical capabilities suggest even more comprehensive support for travelers whose disabilities require ongoing attention.

I've booked a Penthouse Suite on Prestige's inaugural season. My travel advisor specializes in accessible luxury travel and has been in direct communication with Regent's design team. The suite assigned to me will be among the first genuinely luxury accessible accommodations on any ultra-luxury ship—not a retrofitted compromise, but designed from blueprint to serve travelers like me beautifully.

The all-inclusive model matters especially for accessible travelers. Medical equipment transport, specialized shore excursion arrangements, dietary accommodations for disability-related needs—these often incur additional costs elsewhere. Regent's comprehensive inclusion eliminates the financial anxiety that compounds disability's other burdens.

My anticipation extends beyond personal benefit. Prestige represents an industry statement. When the newest, most ambitious ultra-luxury ship integrates accessibility thoroughly, competitors must follow. My visibility aboard Prestige's inaugural—a power wheelchair user experiencing the pinnacle of cruise luxury—becomes advocacy simply by being present.

I'll document everything: what works, what needs improvement, what surpasses expectations. My accessibility travel blog has followed Prestige's construction for three years. Fellow disabled travelers are waiting for my inaugural-voyage report before making their own decisions.

Seven Seas Prestige isn't just a cruise for me. It's the future I've been advocating toward—ultra-luxury that genuinely includes travelers whose bodies work differently.

I'm honored to be among the first to experience it. I'm determined to ensure others can follow.

Prestige launches next year. So does the next chapter of accessible luxury travel.
